summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from July 9, 2019, covering a wide range of national and international news. A significant portion focuses on the federal sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein, including details of his 2008 plea deal brokered by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, and the political fallout. The briefing also covers other criminal investigations, counter-terrorism, counter-intelligence, and various Washington news items.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Charged with sex trafficking and abusing dozens of underage girls. The document details his 2008 plea deal and the new 2019 federal charges.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.context: As U.S. Attorney in Miami in 2008, he brokered the non-prosecution plea deal with Epstein. As Labor Secretary in 2019, he faces calls for his resignation over the deal.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney in Manhattan who announced the new federal sex trafficking charges against Epstein in July 2019.

persons.name: William Sweeney Jr.
persons.context: Assistant Director in charge of the FBI's New York Field Office who urged Epstein's victims to contact the FBI.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to past social ties with Epstein, his praise of Epstein in a 2002 interview, and his administration's handling of the Acosta situation.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as having been a friend of Epstein and flying on his plane. He issued a statement saying he knew nothing about Epstein's crimes.

persons.name: Alan Garten
persons.context: Trump Organization attorney who stated Trump had 'no relationship' with Epstein.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Lawyer who represented Epstein's victims and stated in court documents that Trump had barred Epstein from Mar-A-Lago.

persons.name: Lanny Davis
persons.context: Defended former President Bill Clinton in the wake of the Epstein indictments.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Washington, D.C. attorney who represented Epstein during the 2008 plea deal negotiations with Acosta.

persons.name: Rikki Klieman
persons.context: CBS News legal analyst who commented that Epstein was a 'rich and powerful man with powerful friends' who got away with being a predator.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Mentioned commenting on Democrats subpoenaing Robert Mueller and stating the administration found a legal work-around for the census citizenship question.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, brokered the 2008 non-prosecution plea deal that allowed Epstein to avoid federal charges and serve a lenient sentence.
The document references past social ties, including Trump praising Epstein in a 2002 interview and allegations Epstein was banned from Mar-A-Lago.
Mentioned as a friend who flew on Epstein's plane multiple times.
Lefkowitz was Epstein's attorney during the 2008 plea deal negotiations with Acosta.
Acosta served as Trump's Labor Secretary while facing scrutiny over his role in the Epstein plea deal.

events.title: Epstein Charged with Sex Trafficking
events.description: Federal prosecutors in New York unseal an indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking and abusing dozens of underage girls.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters a non-prosecution agreement with Florida federal prosecutors, pleading guilty to state charges and serving 13 months in jail, avoiding a possible life sentence.

events.title: Trump Praises Epstein in Interview
events.description: Donald Trump praises Jeffrey Epstein in a New York magazine interview, calling him a 'terrific guy' who 'likes beautiful women... on the younger side.'

events.title: Scheduled Mueller Testimony
events.description: Special Counsel Robert Mueller is scheduled to testify before Congress about his report on Russian interference in the 2016 election.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was charged on July 8, 2019, with federal sex trafficking crimes related to abusing dozens of underage girls.
The 2008 plea deal, brokered by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, gave Epstein immunity from federal charges in Florida and a lenient 13-month jail sentence.
The document notes past social connections between Epstein and powerful figures, including Donald Trump and Bill Clinton.
Following the new charges, there were renewed calls for Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta to resign over his handling of the 2008 case.
The FBI established a hotline (1-800-CALL-FBI) for Epstein's victims or those with information to come forward.
